Body: Even with English being a third language to me, the grammatical purport of the suffix "-ter" in words such as "laughter" is easily deducible with only a second's worth of though expended. The affixation of "-ter" is an obvious, though uncommon from my experience, inflectional suffix serving to change a verb, as in "laugh", into a noun. Compare "He laughed at the joke I had told him..." to "His laughter at the joke I had told him...".
